Posts.Content: Hi, so sorry you're feeling so down, it is so early for you that its not surprising you're feeling so down. Don't forget that general anaesthetics alone can make you feel very low and yours was only 4 days ago. Most of us on here are a bit further along the road and while we have all had our VERY low times, we are also getting times when we are feeling positive, mainly due to reading all the 'good news' posts on here. try to think of all the positives you've got already - WLE rather than Mx, SNB rather than having an axillary clearance or removal of lots of sample lymph nodes. Fingers crossed for a good path report from the SNB. Grade 1 is brilliant - celebrate! ER/PR+ve is brilliant - Tamoxifen may get some bad press BUT its a miracle drug offering really good outcomes for ER=Ve cancers, as are the AI drugs for this type of cancer too. Hopefully in a little while we'll see you on here offering positive thoughts to other newly diagnosed women,but in the mean time - don't beat yourself up. You're allowed to be down at the moment but you are surrounded by love and positive thoughts on this site. Big hugs xxx

Posts.Title: Rads THEN chemo - now new skin reaction. Is this normal?

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn, welcome to the site no-one wants to be on! Neutropenic means your white blood cells are low, this is checked before each chemo and is often prevented by an injection given at home 24 hrs after each chemo round, in your tummy fat. Can do this yourself, or get a loved one involved, my daughter does mine, or a district nurse will call in. mets is short for Metasteses, secondary cancer that we are all hoping to avoid, but if they do come are usually in the bones or liver following breast primary. Don't google, can be very scary!! Good luck with everything xx

I'm now worrying reading on here about women still on Tamoxifen while on their Herceptin. Whats the general thought? Are many of you on both or has anyone been told to stop the Tamoxifen? I can't get the image of the Oestrogen receptors all running wild, feeding the cancer, without the Tamoxifen blocking them. Posts.Content: Hi Shelley, so sorry to hear you're having such a bad time. I sympathise so much. I'm also desperate to stay 'on track' to feel better in time for Christmas. I'm there with you with all your side effects - wondered why my nose was sore, I hadn't thought of loosing nose hair until you mentioned it! My nose is also bleeding, which I was a bit worried about but obvious when you think about it! Tax after Rads is the pits. My onc called it 'Recall radiation effect' which I googled and apparently your body sort of reactivates the radiation skin damage as a response to chemo, again something I hadn't been warned to expect when I finished Rads, but a relief to hear. I though the cancer was back in some horrid inflammatory way! So feel free to have a good winge, your husband loves you (mine commented this morning that 'not many women get to see the shape of their heads'!!) and we WILL be finished by Christmas. Posts.Content: This report really wasn't telling us anything new - the inability of anyone to be able to tell which DCIS (pre invasive cancers) will go on to become invasive, and which won't has always been the state. I'm wearing two hats as I work in education and training for the NHS Breast Screening Programme and my current other hat is a natty beany covering my Taxotere thinned and patchy head! Some researchers, specifically Scandinavian but also from the UK, are very anti screening and feel all the money should go into research and treatment but.. 1300 lives a year are saved by screening. Until such a time as we can identify which DCIS will progress and which won't, then the decision for treatment MUST remain with us, the women affected. Hopefully this final, independent report will lead to greater information for women to make their own decisions, but crucially will stop the anti screening campaigners from gaining more publicity. The main danger is if anyone refuses treatment when treatment is their best bet due to misinformation and misinterpretation of the report. If my cancer had been picked up when still DCIS, I would have been DELIGHTED, not worrying about whether the treatment on offer was necessary or not!! Screening + Information all the way - our health, our decisions.
Posts.Title: BBC Report

Posts.Content: I've just been diagnosed with Breast Cancer aged 56. My sister was diagnosed 2 years ago aged 58, my mum was diagnosed at 55 and her grandma at 54. Because we are all post menopausal we have been told that this is not a genetic link that has been identified, but is classed as a 'familial link'. They also say that there is no point in my daughters having early screening, (they're currently 20 and 22) but should have yearly screening from age 50, (hope I'm around to remind them!!). Both my sister's and my cancers were 'true intervals'. ie not seen at routine screening but then presented 1 year later. Mum's was before screening was offered so we don't know but expect that was the same. Its interesting to see the differences in treatment over the years - Gt Grandma had a Radical Mastectomy told to stuff her bra with a sock and died within 2 years. Mum had a modified mastectomy and an external silicone prosthesis. She survived 5 years before getting bone and liver secondries. My sister had a Mx with TRAM flap reconstruction and is alive and well. I had an additional screening at 18 months so was picked up earlier and have just had WLE and clear lymph nodes - start R/T on Monday. Hopefully for my girls it will be an over the chemist counter scan, then a one pill treatment!!
Posts.Title: breast & ovarian risk

Posts.Content: I'm very disapointed to see political campaigning being permitted on this site. INFORMATION is needed for US, the women affected, to make an informed choice. Screening mammography will detect tiny DCIS, many of which may never go on to become full blown invasive cancers, but some of which will. There is currently no way of knowing which. Before screening was widely available, these pre invasive cancers were never seen. Only those that became invasive and thus had 'signs and symptoms' - lumps, dimples, skin puckering etc were investigated. Do we really want to go back to this? My cancer was seen at screening at 3mm of invasive, with 2 cmsof DCIS around it, I was thankfully lymph node free but my cancer was also HER2+ve and thus I am going through chemo and Herceptin. If I hadn't been screened with no symptoms, my cancer would have grown rapidly and my prognosis would have been worse. If I had been screened a few months earlier, it would have still been DCIS and an even better future outcome than the one I thankfully have. We have the information, we can choose.  Choice 1 - don't go for screening, take your chances Choice 2 - if diagnosed with DCIS at screening, accept treatment OR DON'T - wait and see if it becomes invasive. Its not a political issue, the choices are there for us, thank goodness! SIMPLES!
